do that. I would not take the blame for

water. The warrant is being prepared,
she said. Detective Walsh called me.

the house Vanessa asked. You still own
it. I looked at the deed sitting on her

back, not directly, I interrupted. I
want to put it in a trust. The Holloway
Family Trust, I leaned forward. I want

sell it. They cannot mortgage it, and

expression softened. She tilted her

I said. Proceeds go to Alzheimer's
research. I will never live there. I
will never own it again. Vanessa tapped
her pen on the desk. You know, they
might never thank you for this. They
might resent the control. They might
still see you as the daughter who took
over. I know, I said. So why do it? I
thought about my father's shaky
signature. I thought about my mother
standing on the porch terrified of being
abandoned. Because it is the right thing

their approval, Vanessa. I am doing it
because they are elderly and vulnerable

That is it. That is the whole list. I
stood up and walked to the window. I
looked at my reflection in the glass. I
looked tired, but my eyes were clear. I
stopped waiting for them to see me, I
said. I started seeing myself. Vanessa
smiled. It was a genuine, proud smile.
There she is, she said. I smiled back.
Draft the papers, I said. I want it done
before the handcuffs go on. Monday
morning arrived with a sky the color of
a bruised plum. Detective Walsh had
called me at 7:00. The warrant was
executed. The team was rolling out. She
thought I might want to see the end of
the story I had written. I parked my car
three houses down from 147 Lakeshore
Drive. I turned off the engine and
cracked the window. The air was still
biting, but the smell of snow was gone,
replaced by the damp, earthy scent of
mud and thawing grass. I waited. At
9:00, exactly two cruisers turned into
the driveway. They did not use their
sirens. There was no screaming, no
drama, just the quiet, terrifying
efficiency of the law. Detective Walsh
walked to the front door. I watched
through the windshield as my mother
opened it. I saw her hand go to her
throat. I saw the confusion on her face,
the way she looked back into the house
as if calling for help. Then Bethany
appeared. She stepped onto the porch.
She was wearing pajamas. When she saw
the uniforms, she did not freeze. She
ran. She bolted toward the side of the
house, toward the backyard and the woods
beyond, as if she could outrun a felony
indictment in flannel pants. An officer
was already waiting at the corner of the
garage. He stepped out. She stopped. I
watched her shoulders slump. It was the
physical language of defeat. Preston
came out next. He walked with his hands
already raised the muscle memory of a
man who had been in this position
before. He turned around. He let them
cuff him. My parents stood in the
doorway. My father was leaning against
the frame, his face gray. My mother was
covering her mouth, shaking her head.
They looked like ghosts haunting their
own home. The officers led Bethany to
the cruiser. She was shouting now. I
couldn't hear the words, but I saw her
face contorted in a scream. She twisted
in the officer's grip, scanning the
street, looking for an audience, looking
for a scapegoat. Her eyes locked onto my
car. Even from 50 yards away, I felt the
heat of it. Pure distilled hatred. She
lunged toward me, screaming something
that made the veins in her neck bulge
until the officer guided her head down
and pushed her into the back seat. I did
not look away. I did not smile. I looked
at my parents. They were alone on the
porch. The people they had trusted were
in handcuffs. The daughter they had
rejected was watching from a distance. I
started the car. I did not drive up the
driveway. I did not go to comfort them.
That part of my life was over. I put the
car in gear and drove away. 6 weeks
later, the Ontario County Courthouse
smelled of floor wax and old wood. I sat
in the back row. The prosecutor had
offered a deal. It was generous
considering the evidence. Bethany and
Preston were charged with elder
financial abuse, grand lararseny in the
second degree, and forgery. Preston had
an enhancement for his prior fraud
conviction. The judge was a woman with
glasses perched on the end of her nose
and zero patience for tears. She looked
at the defense table. I have reviewed
the forensic accounting provided by the
state. She said, "The paper trail is
exhaustive. Mrs. Crane, you took
advantage of your own father's cognitive
decline. You forged documents. You stole
nearly $200,000.
If you go to trial, I will not be
lenient." Bethany stood up. She was
wearing a beige suit that looked modest,
humble. She had lost the tan. I plead
guilty, your honor. There was no
apology. Not really. Her lawyer read a
statement about how she regretted her
errors in judgment and only wanted to
help her family. She never looked at my
parents who were sitting in the front
row holding hands. She never looked at
me. Four years, the judge said, six for
Mr. Crane. Restitution ordered in the
amount of $180,000.
The gavl banged. It was a hollow wooden
sound. I watched the baoiff lead them
away. I waited for the rush of triumph.
I waited for the joy, but there was only
a quiet, heavy relief. It was like
setting down a backpack I had been
carrying for 15 years. I stood up and
walked out before my parents could turn
around. Two months later, I sat in
Vanessa's office again. The view of the
Albany skyline was the same, but the
documents on the desk were different.
This is the final transfer, Vanessa
said. She looked at me, her pen hovering
over the signature line. Are you sure,
Meredith? You are giving away a4 million
asset. I picked up the pen. The Holloway
Family Trust, I read. The terms were
ironclad. An independent trustee, a
lawyer, and Canandagua would manage the
property. My parents had a life estate.
They could live there until they died.
The trust would pay the taxes, the
insurance, the maintenance, but they
could not sell it. They could not borrow
against it. And Bethany could never ever
touch it. I am sure, I said. I signed my
name. Meredith K. Holloway Grantor. You
are protecting them, Vanessa said
quietly. Even after everything. I put
the pen down. I am protecting them, I
agreed. But I am also freeing myself. If
I kept the house, I would always be
their landlord. I would always be
waiting for them to acknowledge what I
did. This way, it is done. They are
safe. The house is safe. And I am just
me. I slid the papers across the desk.
File it. 6 months after the arrests, the
leaves were turning gold along the
Hudson River. I was sitting in our usual
coffee shop with Vanessa. We were
arguing about where to get lunch. My
phone rang. I looked at the screen.
Mom, I hesitated. The old panic flared
for a second, a phantom limb itching.
Answer it, Vanessa said. Or don't. It is
your choice. That was the difference. It
was my choice. I picked up the phone.
Hello, Mom. Meredith. Her voice sounded
older, thinner. The trustee. Mr.
Henderson called us. He explained the
trust. He explained that you gave us the
house. I took a sip of my coffee. It was
hot and sweet. I wanted to make sure you
were secure, I said. Silence stretched
on the line. I heard her take a shaky
breath. Your father wanted me to call,
she said. He wanted to say, we wanted to
say we are sorry. I closed my eyes. 15
years. I had rehearsed this moment a
thousand times. I had imagined the
weeping, the begging, the grand
reconciliation where they told me I was
the best daughter, the only daughter.
But now that it was here, it felt small.
It felt human. "We should have believed
you," she whispered. "About Bethany,
about everything." "Thank you for saying
that, Mom," I said. My voice was steady.
"I hope you are taking care of dad," I
added. "With the Alzheimer's, we are,"
she said. The trustee helped us hire a
nurse to come in 3 days a week. We are
managing," she paused. "Do you would you
ever want to visit to see him?" I looked
out the window. I saw the river flowing
south, steady and unstopp,"
I said. "When dad is having a good day,
when you are both ready." "But mom, I
need you to understand something." I
waited until I could hear her breathing
on the line. I don't need you to approve
of me anymore, I said gently. I don't
need to prove I am not the person you
thought I was 15 years ago. I know who I
am. I am good at my job. I help people.
I am 14 years sober. I did the right
thing because it was right, not because
I wanted you to love me. Alice was quiet
for a long time. I understand, she said
finally. I will I will call you when we
are ready. Okay, I said. I hung up the
phone. I placed it on the table face
down. Vanessa was watching me. How do
you feel? I took a deep breath. The air
in the coffee shop smelled of roasted
beans and rain. Free, I said. For the
first time in my life, I am actually
free. I picked up my bag. Come on, I
said. We have that 2:00 meeting, the
Harrison fraud case. I walked out the
door and into the autumn sun. I didn't
look back. I had work to do. The
fluorescent lights of the Albany public
library hummed over 18 women. They
looked tired. The sandwich generation
squeezed between raising kids and aging
parents. I adjusted the microphone.
I am not a therapist, I said, my voice
echoing slightly. I am a forensic
accountant, and the hard truth is the
people we love are often the ones who
hurt us the most financially. I clicked
the remote. A slide appeared. Secrecy is
the predator's habitat. My sister stole
nearly $200,000. I told them she didn't
use a gun. She used a sentence. Mom,
Dad, don't worry. I'll handle it. A
woman in the second row nodded,
clutching her purse like a shield. You
have a feeling, don't you? I asked her.
She blinked, tearyeyed. My brother moved
in with mom. Now she says she can't
afford her prescriptions.
That feeling is your evidence, I said.
We are taught that asking about money is
rude, but protecting your parents
dignity includes protecting their
assets. After the talk, she stopped me.
What if he gets angry if I ask to see
the checkbook? Let him be angry, I said.
You aren't doing it for his approval.
You are doing it because it is right.
Walking to my car, the rain had stopped.
My phone buzzed. A text from Alice Dad.
Had a good day. Maybe visit next week.

just a start. I looked in the rearview
mirror. I wasn't just Meredith the

videos.title: Utah Gravel Route - Markagunt Plateau - Volcanos, Aspen Trees, Caves
videos.description:
The Markagunt Plateau is a hidden gem of gravel cycling in southwestern Utah.  Follow me as I discover this secret gravel adventure for the first time.  You will not believe the how the fall colors of the golden aspen leaves pop against the background of black lava flows.  

My gravel adventure started from Zion Adventure Home in Kanab, Utah.  
https://www.moabadventurecondo.com/zion-adventure-home-at-kanab

Follow my route on strava https://www.strava.com/activities/7927569195

I made the scenic 50 mile drive and parked just before Duck Creek Village at the large parking area on Strawberry Point Road.  The are several small diners in the area, if need be you can grab a bite to eat before starting your ride.

From the parking area I started on Dixie National Forest Service Road 64.  This forest service road lead me to the first stop on my tour, Mammoth Cave.  The cave is a series of lava tubes that run just underground.  Even if you are wearing a cycling kit you can get down into the caves and have a look around.  If you are more prepared or perhaps make a return trip you can spend an hour of so exploring the tubes, they run several hundred feet in multiple directions.  To reach the exits you will need shoes you don't mind getting dirty and a good light.  This area is very exciting for kids.  It is important to note that the cave closes from October till spring to protect bat habitat.  

After leaving the lava tubes I made my way along an UTV / ATV trail towards the community of Mammoth.  I don't think there are any services there.  I continued on the main road, route 50 and it soon passed the huge lava fields of Black Rock Valley.   Utah is such a diverse place.  When one thinks about Utah they typically think about the Red Rock deserts such as Moab, or maybe the Wasatch Mountain and ski resorts near Salt Lake City.  I would doubt many people would envision black lava flows that look like Hawaii.  What really sets this area apart is if you come in early October all of the fall leaf colors of golden yellow and blazing orange will make dramatic contrast with the black lava flows.  What an incredible place that not many have heard of.

From Black Rock Valley I made the short detour to Mammoth Springs.  Mammoth Springs is the largest  instantaneous discharge observed at any spring in Utah.  It is really neat to see nothing then a large spring coming out of the no where.  It really is amazing to see so much water just appears.  If you are following my route you could make a change here and skip the lower portions of Black Rock Valley and head straight to Mammoth Springs from the community of Mammoth.  This would eliminate the out and back required to reach the spring and you will still be able to see the best of the lava fields.   

After the 500 foot climb back to route 50 I made my way back to Utah Hwy 143 and turned towards Panguitch.  After about a mile I turned onto Forest Service Road 69 and headed toward Miller Knoll.  WOW, when the aspen trees are just right, this is arguably the most scenic gravel ride in all of Utah.  The golden aspen and the mountains of black lava were truly amazing.  Forget the national parks, this is what you want to see.  I wish I had a way with words, I simply have no better way to describe this area other than breath taking.  I'm sure it is scenic at any time but the first week of October is unreal.  After returning home I have checked my maps and it looks like there are several roads in this area that would be neat, but I stuck to FS69 and headed down the back side of Black Rock Valley.  Another thing to point out in this area is that you will be riding on a custom built UTV trail.  I know that sounds bad to most cyclist but trust me this trail is great, the sweeping berms were sooo much fun.

The story continues on my Southern Utah, Kanab Vacation Rental BLOG at https://www.moabadventurecondo.com/post/markagunt-plateau-secret-gravel-bike-adventure-volcanos-aspen-caves

Die Menschen im Kanton Graubünden sind ebenso weltoffen wie traditionsbewusst. Im Oberengadin locken berühmte Orte wie St. Moritz oder das weitläufige Seenplateau Besucher aus aller Welt, während das Unterengadin mit seinen tiefen Schluchten und wilder Natur begeistert. Auf dem Silsersee leitet Kapitän Franco Giani Europas höchstgelegenen Fährbetrieb. Die Ranger Claudio Irniger und Andri Cuonz kommen im Frühjahr im Schweizerischen Nationalpark dem Wolf auf die Spur. In Zernez veredelt Metzger Ludwig Hatecke hochwertiges Rindfleisch zu Bündner Trockenfleisch und richtet seine Geschäfte wie Luxusboutiquen ein. Holzschnitzerin Nora Engels verwandelt alte Wurzeln mit Kettensäge und Meißel in Kunstwerke. Architekt Duri Vital restauriert jahrhundertealte Engadiner Bauernhäuser. Taraschp Castle. It is one of the most important medieval fortifications in Switzerland.
Within sight of the castle lies the village of Send.
Here, the sculpture park by Dur and his brother Not Vital nestles
against the steep slope. A true playground for art lovers.

quite a bit from its creator, the architect Duri Vital.
It's pretty crazy in the middle. You have to try to stay as still as possible.
The poles are 6 meters high, and if you move even the slightest bit, they start to wobble,
and the ropes are quite low down. So, it's a
matter of total concentration and certainly not for everyone. You're always glad when you're through.

The park's most spectacular artwork is only revealed
when Dori activates it with a remote control.

should somehow be sunk and only raised when people are there.

And because you can't just make real houses disappear seasonally,
the architect wants to preserve the historical buildings of his homeland as faithfully as possible to their original state.
His latest restoration project has just been completed above the sculpture park in the middle of Sent
. Inside the centuries-old Engadine farmhouse,
traditional materials now complement modern interior design.
This is a typical parlor with pine wood. A new
pine wood floor was installed, matching the walls. You can see a bay window in the back.
That's also typical in these parlors, and it was built so that you had a view on
both sides, like the television of yesteryear, to see what was going on outside.
And that used to be the only room that was actually heated, by
this stove that was fired from the kitchen. And there's a staircase leading up there.
In the evenings, they would go up to the bedroom through that hatch at the top. The women, especially
, would go up there, undress on the stove, and then go through
the hatch into the bedroom, which they would leave open so the heat could rise.
They used to sleep upstairs, live in the living room below, and the livestock were kept in the sutera (a type of room).
Duri has faithfully restored the traditional flooring. Yes,
it's now this finished cobblestone floor with the stones from inside. They're only
set in fine gravel so that moisture can escape from the floor and doesn't
seep into the walls. So, you can only sweep the gravel a little with a broom
, but there's absolutely no room for vacuuming; the stones would just fall out again.

Upper Garda. Places like the tranquil Sils and the modern St. Moritz lie along the lakeshores.
In November, temperatures usually drop below freezing. Now,
nature in Upper Garda gradually begins its winter slumber.
The first snow at 1800 meters is just around the corner.
Every year, a unique sculpture is created anew near St. Maitz
. Fifteen men sculpt the Olympic bobsleigh track from snow, ice, and water.
One of the most experienced ice workers is Paul Weitaler. "
I think I'm in my 34th winter working here now. Yes. And it's always a joy to come back. It's just
exhausting. You need a good eye for detail. There are still corrections to be made."

to complete the 1.7-kilometer-long ice sculpture. Racing begins around Christmas.

that really takes its toll on the arms. You have to be reasonably fit and healthy,

, of course, because we're building it by hand. That makes it exciting for the athletes

train here. World Cup races take place several times a season. Amateur athletes
can also test their limits on the natural ice track and enjoy the atmosphere of St. Mauritz.

season. It's simply exhilarating to reach 130-140 km/h under the weight of a skilled pilot.
Sensational. Yes, the special thing is that the track

of speed. Even amateurs can book a ride.

Yes, it's really satisfying to see the track running well now. He had a clearance

past century into a hotspot for the wealthy from all over the world.
Drinking at the champagne bar and luxury shopping are part of the winter sports experience here.
Legendary five-star hotels like the Batrotz Palace attract the international jet set.

that the landscape has transformed overnight into a white wonderland.

thanks to the hardworking draft horses of Werner Wohlend and his team.

which animals are fit for the day's carriage service and which need a short break. "
Here comes the old crew. Retired ones,
they get their pension now. In

. Woli treats his horses like valued employees.

what you're thinking, and that's not very helpful. There are many animals, but
I've never experienced anything as intense as a horse. And I have dogs, sheep,
all wonderful animals. But the horse is something special.

come with the harness, that they look at it willingly and just stand there and don't say, "Oh no, stay away with the
harness." That's why I really make sure that I'm gentle and that they perceive it.
The starting point for the daily trips is the carriage stop in front of Pontesina train station.
The blankets, or "overwraps" as we call them, are for the guests to put over their legs,
because it's quite cold here in the Engadine.
During peak season, the horse-drawn carriage runs four times a day to car-free Wahrrosek. And it runs
in summer too, by the way. I've already turned my hobby into my profession. So, that's for sure. For me,
the best part of driving the carriage is the completely relaxed pace with the horses. That
's also what the guests appreciate, that they can travel up there comfortably. It's stress-free.
Two Gs. Yes, I see the two Gs. What are their names? That's Lisli and Heidi. So.
The horse-drawn carriage is an institution in Upper Engadine. It makes excursions to
Wahrrosek possible at affordable prices. The whip is actually there
to urge the horses on a bit, especially if one horse
is a little slower or thinks, "Nah, I'll let the others pull,
they'll manage," but usually they don't get away with it. As for
the words we use, there are really only a few, and they're quite specific.
The most well-known is "Giddy-up," which probably everyone knows. Then for right
we have "hot," and for left it's "Hiddy-up" or "Therapy." My running bass therapy. Hoppa here. Yes, good.

the fresh air seems to aid the horses' digestion.
We always say that this is our motivation, our turbo boost,
also a bit of humor for the guests, because they always find it very funny.
Everyone always laughs about it. That's normal. Some horses fart more, some less. Therapy.
What I really like about Walro 6 is the car ban. And for me, it's so important that
the horse-drawn carriage tradition continues, because there aren't many carriage companies left that operate on such a large scale.
And I'm also happy to be one of those people who gets to drive a carriage.
The Engadine, a Swiss highland that unfolds its unique magic in every season.
